Package com.rb.nonbiz.search

Class BinarySearchTerminationPredicate<X,​Y>

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.search.BinarySearchTerminationPredicate<X,​Y>
public class BinarySearchTerminationPredicate<X,​Y>
extends java.lang.Object
Instructions on when the binary search should return its result and stop halving the x values.

Say we are doing a binary search to find an x such that f(x) is very near 2, but we don't know f. Let's say that f(x) = x^2, w.l.o.g., but assume we can't know its inverse function, which is sqrt(x). Note that sqrt(2) = 1.41421356. Let's say we start the binary search with x bounds [1.0, 2.0].

We could terminate if the binary search is:

  1. looking at an x interval that is very small, e.g. x in [1.41, 1.42]
  2. looking at a y interval that is very small, e.g. y in [1.9, 2.1]
  3. #1 OR #2
  4. #1 AND #2

This data class abstracts away those 4 cases. Its inner state is intentionally not made available, but the point is that you just call test(Object, Object, Object, Object) (using 'test' in the 'test predicate' sense per Java naming convention, not in the unit test sense).

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    static <X,​ Y> BinarySearchTerminationPredicate<X,​Y> onlyTerminateBasedOnX​(java.util.function.BiPredicate<X,​X> xPredicate)

    static <X,​ Y> BinarySearchTerminationPredicate<X,​Y> onlyTerminateBasedOnY​(java.util.function.BiPredicate<Y,​Y> yPredicate)
    Terminates the binary search when the predicate on Y is true; we don't care about X here.

    Terminates the binary search when EITHER predicate on X or Y is true.
    static <X,​ Y> BinarySearchTerminationPredicate<X,​Y> terminateBasedOnXorY​(java.util.function.BiPredicate<X,​X> xPredicate, java.util.function.BiPredicate<Y,​Y> yPredicate)
    Terminates the binary search when BOTH predicates on X and Y are true.
